ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned some basics of solid state physics.

Crystal structures, symmetry groups, lattice/basic phonon theory, electron models (Drude, Sommerfeld, Band Theory), semiconductors, devices, basic solid phase transitions. I gained a much deeper understanding of all the approximations and ways in which the properties of solids are predicted and considered.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The lectures were unorganized and unilluminating, and the problem sets often depended on just finding the right formula in the book instead of understanding the material.
Lecturing did not provide sufficient explanations for concepts while examinations were overly explanation heavy and mathematically lacking.

Strengths: Breadth and depth of material. Good texts and very interesting physical properties of materials explored. Weaknesses: Only adequate professor and very little ability to go beyond the set course material.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Take it if it is a requirement. Audit or credit-d if possible
If you're interested in learning about solidstate physics, just read it out of the two textbooks, that's what you'll be doing in this class anyways.

Yes. I felt that the material was extremely interesting and the pace of the class was adequate (very rare for me). I highly recommend reading the text books as lecture provides a nice supplementary understanding/interpretation and the texts provide rigor. Honestly, the professor is not the most inspiring, however, I felt that lecture always helped me understand material which was not at first clear to me upon reading it exactly the model of a good grad class.
